com.camerontec.util.collection

Interface ICollectionRegistry

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    IDistributedCollectionRegistry
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractCollectionRegistry, CollectionRegistryService, DistributedCollectionRegistry, StandaloneCollectionRegistry

    public interface ICollectionRegistry
    Interface to the registry of persisted collections.

    Conceptually the registry is a map of persisted collections keyed by object name. Regardless of type, successive calls to retrieve an object by name result in the same object being returned.

    The caller may assume that the collections returned are:

    • Thread safe
    • HA aware

    The caller should be aware, however, that operations on HA aware collections may be temporarily blocked by underlying data synchronization activities.

    Applicable Properties are defined by CollectionProperties. However, it is worth mentioning here that all collections require that at least the CollectionProperties.DIRECTORY_NAME be specified.

    In general there are 2 variants available for obtaining a collection of a particular type (e.g. 2 variants for List and 2 variants for Maps) and these are associated with how the collection keys and values are serialized and deserialized.

    When using variants of the form: 

     List<E> list = getList(properties, E.class)
 Map<K,V> map = getMap(properties, K.class, V.class)
    the underlying implementation chooses the most appropriate IBytesSegmentExternalizer instance to use for serialization and deserialization.

    Built in implementations are available for the following classes:

    • BytesSegment.class
    • String.class (Strings are written/read in modified UTF format as specified by java.io.DataInput)
    • Boolean.class
    • Short.class
    • Integer.class
    • Float.class
    • Long.class
    • Double.class
    • Any java.lang.Object which is also java.io.Serializable. This is the default option when no other externalizer is suitable. Note that this choice is potentially less efficient and so callers should take that into consideration when choosing this option. An alternative is to provide a custom externalizer - see below.

    All built in externalizers are thread safe.

    When none of the built in externalizers are sufficient the caller may supply custom IBytesSegmentExternalizer implementations as appropriate the other variant for the desired collection type.

    In either case and when being used in an HA context, updates to collections are serialized and distributed to other nodes in the cluster. It is for this reason that the size of any single update (i.e. serialized representation of key and value) is limited in size. The underlying distribution mechanism does not handle fragmentation and re-assembly of payloads above 64 KB (at the time of this writing).

    Nested collections, defined here as collections like this: 

     List<Map<K, V>>
 Map<K, List<E>>
 ...
    can be supported, but care is required on the part of the caller. In such cases it is easy to accidentally subvert the persistence and distribution mechanism unless updates are made via the outer collection.

    That is, the following code will not behave as expected: 

     Map<String, List<Integer>> mapOfLists = ...
 ...
 List<Integer> list = mapOfLists.get("key");
 list.add(10);
    unless it is followed by the following update to the outer collection: 
     mapOfLists.put("key", list);
    which is intercepted and handled correctly, though efficiency is still a consideration. In the above case the entire list is serialized and persisted (and possibly distributed) when put into the map even though only a single element was added.
    See Also:
    CollectionProperties

    • Method Detail

      • getList

        <E> List<E> getList(String name,
                    Properties properties,
                    Class<E> elementClass)
             throws IOException
        Return a named list from the registry, creating and inserting one if none exists.

        This variant assumes the element class may be externalized by one of the built in externalizers, or is java.io.Serializable. If custom externalization is required use getList(String, Properties, com.camerontec.util.io.IBytesSegmentExternalizer) instead.

        Lists may be either standard or high capacity. The caller may choose by optionally specifying the CollectionProperties.IS_HIGH_CAPACITY_LIST property.

        Lists do not currently support in memory element caching.

        Type Parameters:
        E - The element type.
        Parameters:
        name - the list's name - this name has to be unique across all collections managed by this registry
        properties - The list properties.
        elementClass - The element class.
        Returns:
        The named list.
        Throws:
        IOException - On error creating a new list.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the given name is already used

      • getList

        <E> List<E> getList(String name,
                    Properties properties,
                    Class<E> elementClass,
                    ProgressReporter progressReporter)
             throws IOException

        See Also:

      • getMap

        <K,V> Map<K,V> getMap(String name,
                      Properties properties,
                      Class<K> keyClass,
                      Class<V> valueClass)
               throws IOException
        Return a named map from the registry, creating and inserting one if none exists.

        This variant assumes the element class may be externalized by one of the built-in externalizer, or is java.io.Serializable. If custom externalization is required use getMap(String, Properties, IBytesSegmentExternalizer, IBytesSegmentExternalizer, Map) instead.

        We assume that caching is enabled by default. Should any one need to disable caching explicitly using this method, set the property CollectionProperties.IS_CACHING_ENABLED to false in the supplied properties parameter.

        By default the cache implementation used is BoundedLRUCache. If this implementation is not sufficient a custom cache may be used by calling getMap(String, Properties, IBytesSegmentExternalizer, IBytesSegmentExternalizer, Map) instead.

        There is no concept of a high capacity map.

        Type Parameters:
        K - The key type.
        V - The value type.
        Parameters:
        name - the map's name - this name has to be unique across all collections managed by this registry
        properties - The map properties.
        keyClass - Class of the key in the map.
        valueClass - Class of the value in the map
        Returns:
        The named Map with the specified types.
        Throws:
        IOException - On error creating a new map.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the given name is already used

      • getMap

        <K,V> Map<K,V> getMap(String name,
                      Properties properties,
                      Class<K> keyClass,
                      Class<V> valueClass,
                      ProgressReporter progressReporter)
               throws IOException
        Return a named map from the registry, creating and inserting one if none exists.
        Type Parameters:
        K - The key type.
        V - The value type.
        Parameters:
        name - the map's name - this name has to be unique across all collections managed by this registry
        properties - The map properties.
        keyClass - Class of the key in the map.
        valueClass - Class of the value in the map
        progressReporter - Progress reporter for scan and compact operations.
        Returns:
        The named Map with the specified types.
        Throws:
        IOException - On error creating a new map.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the given name is already used
        See Also:
        getMap(String, Properties, Class, Class)

      • getMap

        <K,V> Map<K,V> getMap(String name,
                      Properties properties,
                      IBytesSegmentExternalizer<K> keyExternalizer,
                      IBytesSegmentExternalizer<V> valueExternalizer)
               throws IOException
        Returns a named map from the registry, creating and inserting one if none exists.

        Use this method if you want to plug custom externalizers but use the default cache.

        Type Parameters:
        K - The key type.
        V - The value type.
        Parameters:
        name - the map's name - this name has to be unique across all collections managed by this registry
        properties - The properties of the map.
        keyExternalizer - The custom key externalizer.
        valueExternalizer - The custom value externalizer.
        Returns:
        The named Map with the specified types.
        Throws:
        IOException - On error creating a map.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the given name is already used
        See Also:
        getMap(String, Properties, Class, Class)

      • getMap

        <K,V> Map<K,V> getMap(String name,
                      Properties properties,
                      IBytesSegmentExternalizer<K> keyExternalizer,
                      IBytesSegmentExternalizer<V> valueExternalizer,
                      Map<K,V> customCache)
               throws IOException
        Returns a named map from the registry, creating and inserting one if none exists.

        Use this method if you want to plug in a custom cache and/or custom externalizers.

        Type Parameters:
        K - The key type.
        V - The value type.
        Parameters:
        name - the map's name - this name has to be unique across all collections managed by this registry
        properties - The properties of the map.
        keyExternalizer - The custom key externalizer.
        valueExternalizer - The custom value externalizer.
        customCache - Custom cache. May be null if caching is disabled.
        Returns:
        The named Map with the specified types.
        Throws:
        IOException - On error creating a map.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the given name is already used
        See Also:
        getMap(String, Properties, Class, Class)

      • remove

        boolean remove(String name)
        throws IOException
        Remove a named collection from the registry.
        Parameters:
        name - The collection name.
        Returns:
        True if the name collection was removed, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        IOException - On error removing the named collection.

      • isRegistered

        boolean isRegistered(String name)
        Returns whether there is currently a collection registered under the given name in the registry.
        Parameters:
        name - The name.
        Returns:
        true if a collection is currently bound to that name, false otherwise.

      • names

        Returns the names of all currently registered collections.
        Returns:
        The names of all the collections currently registered.

      • compact

        void compact(String name)
        Compact the collection of the specified name.

        If the specified collection is not ICompactable then this call will be ignored.

        Parameters:
        name - Name of collection to compact.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If there is nothing bound to the given name in the registry.

      • refresh

        void refresh(String name)
        Refresh the collection of the specified name from disk.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of collection to refresh.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If there is nothing bound to the given name in the registry.

      • close

        void close(String name)
    throws IOException
        Closes the collection of the specified name, allowing underlying resources to be freed.

        If the specified collection is already closed, then this call will have no effect.

        A collection should never be used after being closed. Doing this has unspecified effects.

        Parameters:
        name - Name of collection to close.
        Throws:
        IOException - If an I/O error occurs when releasing some resource used by the collection
        IllegalArgumentException - If there is nothing bound to the given name in the registry.

      • closeAll

        void closeAll()
       throws IOException
        Closes all the collections bound to this registry that are not already closed.

        A collection should never be used after being closed. Doing this has unspecified effects.

        Throws:
        IOException - If an I/O error occurs when releasing some resource used by a collection
        See Also:
        close(String)
